title: Ghana Domain Name Registry Bill – formerly provided for in Electronic Transactions Act
summary:
The Ghana Domain Name Registry Bill establishes a comprehensive regulatory framework for managing Ghana's .gh domain name system. The bill creates the **Ghana Domain Name Registry** as a self-governing, non-profit entity governed by a presidentially-appointed board with mandatory gender representation ([5](#5-governing-body-of-the-registry)). The Registry will manage the .gh domain space, license registrars, and operate a **DNS Security Operations Centre** to monitor and protect against cyber threats ([18](#18-domain-name-system-dns-security-operations-centre)).

The bill's most significant provision mandates that **all legally registered entities in Ghana must register and use a .gh domain name** for their official online presence and digital communications, with a six-month transition period for existing entities ([19](#19-mandatory-registration)). Non-compliance carries substantial penalties: annual fines of 1,000-10,000 penalty units, potential business license suspension or revocation, and exclusion from public contracts for up to two years ([21](#21-penalties-for-non-compliance)). Corporate directors who knowingly permit violations face personal fines up to 5,000 penalty units. The Registry will publicly list non-compliant entities ([23](#23-entities-in-breach)) and can obtain court orders to seize or block violating domain names ([24](#24-court-orders-and-judicial-support)). Limited exemptions exist for entities whose digital operations are based outside Ghana, don't target Ghanaian users, and are subject to foreign digital laws ([20](#20-exemptions)).

The bill establishes robust financial mechanisms to support digital development. The Registry operates tax-exempt ([28](#28-tax-exemption)) and receives funding from Parliament, the Digital Economy and Innovation Development Fund, service fees, and donations ([25](#25-funds-of-the-registry)). A separate **Domain Name Registry Fund** prioritizes projects supporting SME digital capabilities and domain name system improvements ([36](#36-prioritisation-of-the-fund)). The Registry can borrow with government guarantees subject to Finance Minister approval ([27](#27-borrowing-powers-of-the-registry)).

The regulatory framework includes structured dispute resolution through a specialized five-member **Dispute Resolution Committee** with expertise in intellectual property and internet law ([39](#39-dispute-resolution-committee)). Parties must exhaust this process before court action, with decisions issued within 30 days and appeals available to the High Court ([38](#38-resolution-of-disputes)). The bill requires annual reporting to Parliament and public disclosure of Registry activities ([30](#30-annual-report-and-other-reports)), while the Minister retains authority to issue policy directives for domain space management ([10](#10-policy-directives)). Operating as an unlicensed registrar carries penalties, and the Registry has 60 days to process license applications ([15](#15-operation-as-a-registrar), [16](#16-application-for-a-registrar-licence)).

description.analysis:
The Ghana Domain Name Registry Bill creates a **highly restrictive environment for digital innovation** through mandatory domain requirements and severe enforcement mechanisms. The bill's core mandate requiring all legally registered entities to register and use .gh domains for official digital presence ([19](#19-mandatory-registration)) fundamentally constrains entrepreneurial freedom and digital strategy flexibility. Startups and innovative digital businesses often rely on globally recognized domain extensions (.com, .io, .tech) to establish international credibility and reach global markets. Forcing exclusive use of .gh domains could **undermine Ghana's competitiveness** in attracting digital entrepreneurs and tech companies, particularly those building products for international markets.

The **penalty structure creates substantial barriers to innovation**. Non-compliant entities face annual fines of 1,000-10,000 penalty units, potential business license suspension or revocation, and exclusion from public procurement for up to two years ([21](#21-penalties-for-non-compliance)). For early-stage startups and SMEs operating on tight budgets, these penalties represent existential risks that could force business closures or deter digital entrepreneurship entirely. The personal liability imposed on corporate directors (up to 5,000 penalty units) further discourages risk-taking and innovation. Additionally, the broad discretionary powers to suspend or revoke registrar licenses ([17](#17-suspension-and-revocation-of-licences)) and the general penalty provision ([41](#41-general-penalty)) create an unpredictable regulatory environment that increases compliance costs and uncertainty.

While the establishment of a **DNS Security Operations Centre** ([18](#18-domain-name-system-dns-security-operations-centre)) provides valuable cybersecurity infrastructure for monitoring threats and coordinating responses, this positive contribution is significantly outweighed by the restrictive mandates. The bill prioritizes regulatory control over creating an enabling environment for digital innovation. The six-month transition period is particularly challenging for established digital businesses that have built brand recognition and SEO rankings on non-.gh domains. Overall, this legislation is likely to **suppress digital innovation, increase operational costs, and reduce Ghana's attractiveness** as a destination for technology entrepreneurship and digital business development.

This bill creates significant risks to **freedom of speech and expression** through provisions that establish extensive surveillance infrastructure and domain blocking powers without adequate safeguards. The **DNS Security Operations Centre** ([18](#18-domain-name-system-dns-security-operations-centre)) will monitor all .gh domain "resolutions, traffic, and logs" and can initiate "containment" and "mitigation" actions. While framed as cybersecurity measures, these capabilities create a comprehensive monitoring system over digital communications that could be used to track and restrict lawful expression. The broad discretion to determine what constitutes a "threat" requiring response, combined with limited transparency (only quarterly public reports), raises concerns about potential overreach into content moderation or suppression of dissent.

The power to **seize, block, or deactivate domain names** ([24](#24-court-orders-and-judicial-support)) represents a severe restriction on expression, as it eliminates an entity's entire online presence rather than addressing specific problematic content. While the provision requires High Court orders, it lacks clear standards defining when blocking is appropriate, procedural protections for affected parties to be heard before action, or explicit exemptions for journalistic, political, or other protected speech. Domain blocking is a blunt instrument that affects all content on a site, including lawful expression, and can effectively silence organizations, media outlets, or individuals. The bill provides no requirement that less restrictive alternatives be considered before resorting to complete domain deactivation.

The combination of these provisions creates infrastructure that, while potentially justified for legitimate cybersecurity purposes, could be misused to restrict critical journalism, political opposition, or civil society advocacy. The bill would benefit from explicit protections for lawful speech, narrower definitions of blockable offenses, mandatory judicial pre-approval with expedited hearings, and transparency requirements for all blocking actions. Without such safeguards, the Registry's broad monitoring and blocking powers pose **substantial risks to digital freedom of expression** in Ghana.

The Ghana Domain Name Registry Bill introduces **significant privacy concerns** through its establishment of a centralized surveillance infrastructure and broad investigative powers. The mandatory **DNS Security Operations Centre** ([18](#18-domain-name-system-dns-security-operations-centre)) will continuously monitor domain resolutions, traffic, and logs across all .gh domains, with compulsory integration for government entities. This creates a comprehensive monitoring system that can track internet usage patterns, website visits, and digital communications routing across Ghana's domain space. While framed as a cybersecurity measure, the provision lacks critical privacy safeguards such as data minimization principles, retention limits, access controls, or transparency requirements about what information is collected and how it may be used or shared.

The bill's **court order provisions** ([24](#24-court-orders-and-judicial-support)) compound these privacy risks by granting the Registry authority to apply for orders authorizing entry into premises to inspect digital systems under warrant. This power could enable access to servers, databases, and digital infrastructure containing sensitive personal data, business information, and confidential communications. While requiring judicial approval provides some oversight, the bill does not establish specific standards for when such intrusive measures are justified or require consideration of privacy impacts. The combination of continuous monitoring and investigative powers creates a framework where the Registry has extensive visibility into and potential access to digital activities and data.

**Critically, the bill operates in isolation from data protection principles**, with no reference to Ghana's Data Protection Act or requirements to implement privacy-by-design approaches. There are no provisions for data subject rights, no limitations on secondary use of collected information, and no independent privacy oversight of the Registry's monitoring activities. The quarterly and yearly threat reports mentioned in [18](#18-domain-name-system-dns-security-operations-centre) focus on security metrics but include no transparency requirements about privacy practices or data handling. For individuals and businesses operating under .gh domains, this creates uncertainty about what information about their digital activities may be collected, retained, analyzed, or potentially shared with other government entities, representing a **substantial erosion of privacy expectations** in Ghana's digital ecosystem.

This bill imposes **severe operational and financial burdens** on Ghana's business community through mandatory domain requirements and punitive enforcement mechanisms. The **mandatory .gh domain registration** ([19](#19-mandatory-registration)) requires all legally registered entities to register and maintain active .gh domains for official websites and use them for all official digital correspondence within six months. This forces businesses to restructure their digital infrastructure, potentially abandoning established international domains, disrupting email systems, and reconfiguring digital operations—all at significant cost. For businesses with established online presences, this represents a forced migration that could disrupt customer relationships, search engine rankings, and brand recognition.

The **penalty structure creates existential business risks** that go far beyond typical regulatory fines. Non-compliant entities face annual fines of 1,000-10,000 penalty units ([21](#21-penalties-for-non-compliance)), but more critically, they risk **suspension or revocation of business licenses** and **disqualification from public procurement for up to two years**. For businesses dependent on government contracts, this effectively means potential business closure. Directors face **personal liability** up to 5,000 penalty units for knowing violations, creating individual legal exposure that may deter business leadership. The Registry maintains **public lists of non-compliant entities** ([23](#23-entities-in-breach)) and can publish names in newspapers and government gazettes, adding reputational damage to financial penalties. The Registry's power to seek court orders to **seize, block, or deactivate domains** ([24](#24-court-orders-and-judicial-support)) represents the ultimate business threat—the ability to shut down a company's digital presence entirely.

The **regulatory framework imposes multiple layers of compliance burden** that increase operational complexity and costs. Businesses must navigate a **monopolistic registry structure** ([4](#4-functions-of-the-registry)) with no competitive alternatives, comply with ministerial policy directives ([10](#10-policy-directives)) that can change "from time to time," and work through registrars subject to 60-day licensing processes ([16](#16-application-for-a-registrar-licence)) and potential suspension or revocation ([17](#17-suspension-and-revocation-of-licences)). A **Domain Compliance Unit** ([22](#22-monitoring-and-inspection)) will actively audit and monitor domain usage, creating ongoing compliance surveillance. While narrow exemptions exist for entities with exclusively foreign operations not targeting Ghanaian users ([20](#20-exemptions)), most businesses operating in Ghana will face full compliance requirements. The combination of forced infrastructure changes, severe penalties including business closure, personal director liability, public shaming, and complex regulatory oversight creates a fundamentally hostile environment that will increase costs, reduce operational flexibility, and potentially drive businesses to relocate operations outside Ghana.

keyConcerns.title: Mass Surveillance Without Data Protection
keyConcerns.description: The DNS Security Operations Centre will monitor **"domain resolutions, traffic, and logs"** for all .gh domains, but the provision contains **no privacy safeguards, data minimization principles, or independent oversight**. Combined with mandatory .gh domain use ([19](#19-mandatory-registration)), this creates a system where all legally registered entities must route their digital operations through government-monitored infrastructure. The provision violates **GDPR principles** (no data minimization, purpose limitation, or transparency), **ICCPR Article 17** (arbitrary interference with privacy), and **OECD privacy guidelines** by establishing mass surveillance without specifying what data is collected, how long it's retained, who can access it, or whether judicial authorization is required.

keyConcerns.title: Universal Business Licensing Through Domain Control
keyConcerns.description: This provision mandates that **all legally registered entities** must register and use .gh domains for official websites and **all official digital correspondence and transactions**. This operates as a universal licensing requirement backed by business license suspension/revocation ([21](#21-penalties-for-non-compliance)) and public contract exclusion. Unlike sector-specific regulations, this captures every business operating in Ghana's digital economy, eliminating competitive infrastructure choice and creating a single point of control over business market access. The narrow exemptions in [20](#20-exemptions) require foreign hosting AND foreign jurisdiction, effectively excluding domestic businesses entirely.

keyConcerns.title: **Statutory Monopoly Eliminates Competition**
keyConcerns.description: The provision establishes the Registry as **"the only domain name Registry"** with exclusive control over Ghana's .gh domain space, creating a statutory monopoly without competitive alternatives. While the Registry can license multiple registrars (1(f)), the Registry itself operates as an exclusive monopoly, preventing market competition in registry services. Combined with the government-controlled board structure in [5](#5-governing-body-of-the-registry), this creates a single point of control over critical digital infrastructure that businesses must use, eliminating competitive pressure for service quality and innovation.

keyConcerns.title: Executive-Dominated Board Enforces Mandatory Registration
keyConcerns.description: The Board governing the Registry is **majority-controlled by executive appointees** (President appoints all members; at least 3 of 8 are executive-aligned), creating a governance structure biased toward aggressive enforcement of the **mandatory .gh registration requirement** rather than business-friendly policies. The Board includes the **Executive Director** (who benefits from Registry growth through enforcement) and a **licensed registrar representative** (who may benefit from competitors facing penalties), creating conflicts of interest where the governing body profits from enforcement. Only one member represents the business community subject to mandatory registration, while **no structural separation exists between policy-making and enforcement functions**—the same Board governs both the monopoly operator and the enforcer of substantial penalties ([21](#21-penalties-for-non-compliance)).

keyConcerns.title: Unilateral Ministerial Rule-Making Power
keyConcerns.description: The Minister can publish binding policy directives for the .gh domain space **without parliamentary approval or public consultation**. Given that all registered entities must comply with mandatory .gh registration ([19](#19-mandatory-registration)) and face severe penalties for non-compliance—including business license suspension and public contract exclusion ([21](#21-penalties-for-non-compliance))—this creates **significant regulatory uncertainty**. Businesses cannot predict compliance requirements when rules can change at ministerial discretion, chilling investment and making long-term planning difficult.

keyConcerns.title: Monopoly Structure with Discretionary Licensing
keyConcerns.description: The provision establishes the Registry as the **sole authority** to maintain Ghana's domain registry, explicitly prohibiting alternative repositories with criminal penalties up to **10,000 penalty units** for corporate violations. While the 60-day licensing timeline provides structure, the Registry can impose "**terms and conditions where the Registry deems it appropriate**" without legislative limits, and technical requirements are prescribed by the Registry itself rather than defined in law. Combined with vague suspension grounds in [17](#17-suspension-and-revocation-of-licences) ("misconduct," "abuse"), this creates a **high-barrier, discretionary licensing regime within a monopoly structure**. Since all legally registered entities must use .gh domains, this eliminates competitive pressure and concentrates substantial market control in a single entity with undefined discretionary powers—more restrictive than typical OECD infrastructure licensing practice.

keyConcerns.title: Vague License Revocation Chills Innovation
keyConcerns.description: The Registry can suspend or revoke registrar licenses for undefined **"misconduct"** or **"abuse"** without requiring notice, hearing, or written reasons. This regulatory uncertainty discourages market entry and innovation—potential registrars cannot assess compliance risk when standards are vague and enforcement is discretionary. The provision states it **"does not limit"** additional Registry powers, creating unlimited regulatory exposure. Combined with mandatory .gh domain requirements ([19](#19-mandatory-registration)), this gives the Registry unchecked power over digital infrastructure, undermining the competitive registrar market essential for digital innovation.

keyConcerns.title: Arbitrary License Revocation Threatens Registrars
keyConcerns.description: The Registry can **suspend or revoke registrar licenses** on vague grounds like "misconduct which harms consumers or the public interest" or "failure to meet ongoing requirements prescribed by the Minister"—without requiring notice, hearing, written reasons, or appeal rights. This creates severe **regulatory uncertainty** for registrars as businesses: they cannot clearly understand what conduct triggers license loss, cannot defend themselves before revocation, and face undefined compliance obligations that can change at ministerial discretion. Combined with [19](#19-mandatory-registration)'s mandatory .gh domain requirement, this gives the Registry unchecked power to exclude businesses from the domain registration market without basic procedural safeguards standard in OECD regulatory frameworks.

keyConcerns.title: Mandatory Government Infrastructure Deters Innovation
keyConcerns.description: This provision establishes a **DNS Security Operations Centre** that monitors all .gh domain "resolutions, traffic, and logs" using automated or manual methods. Combined with the mandatory .gh domain requirement in [19](#19-mandatory-registration), this forces all businesses to route their digital operations through government-controlled infrastructure with broad monitoring capabilities. The provision lacks **data minimization principles, independent oversight, or privacy safeguards**, creating uncertainty for digital entrepreneurs. This infrastructure lock-in and surveillance concern deters digital innovation by removing business choice in infrastructure providers and creating competitive disadvantages compared to jurisdictions with optional, competitive domain systems.

keyConcerns.title: Government Surveillance Without Privacy Safeguards
keyConcerns.description: The DNS Security Operations Centre monitors **all .gh domain "resolutions, traffic, and logs"** using automated or manual methods. Combined with the mandatory .gh domain requirement in [19](#19-mandatory-registration), this creates government surveillance of all legally registered entities' digital communications. The provision lacks critical privacy safeguards: no data minimization, no independent oversight, no judicial authorization for monitoring, and no user notification. This broad monitoring scope without procedural safeguards creates **chilling effects on digital expression** and violates international standards for privacy and freedom of expression (ICCPR Articles 17 and 19).

keyConcerns.title: Mandatory Government Infrastructure Monitoring
keyConcerns.description: This provision requires all .gh domains to be monitored by a government-controlled DNS Security Operations Centre that tracks "domain resolutions, traffic, and logs." Combined with the mandatory .gh domain requirement in [19](#19-mandatory-registration), this forces **all legally registered businesses** to route their digital operations through government infrastructure with broad monitoring capabilities. This eliminates market choice in infrastructure providers, creates **business confidentiality risks** (as proprietary communications and customer data flows are subject to government observation), and imposes compliance costs particularly burdensome for SMEs. The provision lacks safeguards for trade secrets or competitive information, creating a **competitive disadvantage** for Ghana-based businesses versus international competitors and deterring foreign investment in Ghana's digital economy.

keyConcerns.title: Forced Government Infrastructure Dependency
keyConcerns.description: This provision **mandates that all entities use .gh domains** for official websites and digital communications, creating a government-controlled infrastructure dependency for digital innovation. Startups and digital businesses cannot choose domain infrastructure based on technical merit or cost—they must use the Registry's infrastructure regardless of competitive alternatives. This **technology lock-in backed by business license revocation** creates a significant barrier to market entry and chills innovation by forcing businesses onto a single entity's terms, contrary to the competitive infrastructure choice found in OECD digital economies.

keyConcerns.title: Narrow Exemption Criteria Exclude Legitimate Businesses
keyConcerns.description: The exemption requires entities to meet **all three conditions simultaneously**: exclusive hosting outside Ghana, no targeting of Ghanaian users, AND multinational status with foreign digital jurisdiction. This excludes many legitimate business scenarios—regional African businesses serving multiple countries, diaspora enterprises with Ghanaian customers, and foreign companies with Ghanaian subsidiaries all fail to qualify. Combined with **discretionary approval** ("may grant") and vague criteria like "does not target Ghanaian users," businesses face uncertainty about whether they qualify. When paired with severe penalties in [21](#21-penalties-for-non-compliance) (annual fines up to 10,000 penalty units, license revocation, and public procurement exclusion), this narrow exemption framework creates substantial barriers to foreign investment and regional business integration.

keyConcerns.title: Severe Penalties Deter Digital Entrepreneurship
keyConcerns.description: This provision imposes **business-ending penalties** for non-compliance with mandatory .gh domain registration: annual fines up to 10,000 penalty units, **license revocation**, and **two-year public procurement exclusion**. For digital startups and SMEs—the primary drivers of innovation—these penalties create existential risks over technical compliance matters. The undefined **"repeated non-compliance"** threshold and lack of explicit cure periods create enforcement uncertainty that deters digital experimentation. Combined with [19](#19-mandatory-registration) requiring ALL entities to use .gh domains, this effectively mandates participation in government infrastructure under threat of business exclusion—a significant departure from innovation-friendly regulatory approaches that allow digital autonomy.

keyConcerns.title: License Revocation Without Clear Standards
keyConcerns.description: This provision authorizes **license suspension or revocation** for "repeated non-compliance" with [19](#19-mandatory-registration)'s .gh domain requirement, but fails to define what constitutes "repeated" violations. Businesses face existential threats—including **public procurement exclusion for up to two years**—without clear enforcement thresholds or explicit due process protections before coercive action. These consequences are **disproportionate** to a technical domain registration requirement and create enforcement uncertainty that undermines business planning and market participation.

keyConcerns.title: Self-Interested Enforcement Without Safeguards
keyConcerns.description: The provision creates a **Domain Compliance Unit** staffed by Registry officers and ministerially-appointed persons to audit domain usage and serve compliance notices. This structure embeds a **conflict of interest**: the Registry, which profits from domain registrations and registrar licensing ([25](#25-funds-of-the-registry)), controls the enforcement mechanism that triggers severe penalties ([21](#21-penalties-for-non-compliance)). The provision provides **no independence safeguards, audit scope limits, or pre-notice hearing rights**, creating regulatory uncertainty where businesses face unpredictable enforcement by a self-interested regulator. Combined with undefined "audit and monitor domain name usage" authority, this discourages market entry and innovation.

keyConcerns.title: Public Shaming Without Due Process
keyConcerns.description: The Registry must publish lists of non-compliant entities on its website and may publish names in **national newspapers and government gazettes**. However, the provision lacks critical procedural safeguards: no notice before publication, no opportunity to cure violations before public naming, no clear criteria for removal after compliance, and no proportionality review. Combined with severe penalties including **license suspension and contract exclusion** ([21](#21-penalties-for-non-compliance)), this creates substantial reputational harm that can permanently damage businesses even after they achieve compliance. The vague "fundamental human rights" consideration clause provides no operational protection against disproportionate public shaming for technical or administrative violations.

keyConcerns.title: Domain Seizure Without Speech Protections
keyConcerns.description: The Registry can obtain court orders to **seize, block, or deactivate domain names** without requiring notice to the domain owner, a hearing opportunity, or appeal rights before execution. Since domain names are essential infrastructure for online speech, this power enables **immediate silencing of online expression** based on technical registration violations under the mandatory .gh requirement ([19](#19-mandatory-registration)). The provision makes no distinction between domains used for speech versus purely commercial purposes, and the **"reasonable suspicion" standard for premises entry** to "inspect digital systems" could expose private communications and unpublished content without adequate safeguards.

keyConcerns.title: Warrantless Digital Surveillance Powers
keyConcerns.description: The provision authorizes **premises entry to "inspect digital systems"** based only on **"reasonable suspicion of concealment or fraud"**—a vague, low evidentiary threshold. This grants access to potentially all business data systems (servers, databases, emails, customer records) without specifying what information can be collected, how long it can be retained, or restrictions on secondary use. The provision lacks fundamental **data protection safeguards**: no limits on data collection scope, no notification to affected data subjects, and no independent oversight of how collected information is used. This creates disproportionate surveillance authority for administrative domain registration enforcement.

keyConcerns.title: Broad Premises Inspection Without Safeguards
keyConcerns.description: The Registry can obtain court orders to **enter business premises and inspect digital systems** based on "reasonable suspicion of concealment or fraud"—a vague, low threshold that creates operational uncertainty. The provision provides **no notice requirements, no limits on what digital systems can be inspected, and no appeal rights before warrant execution**, allowing access to proprietary business information, financial records, and customer data far beyond domain registration matters. Combined with mandatory .gh registration ([19](#19-mandatory-registration)), this subjects all legally registered entities to potential premises entry for infrastructure compliance violations, creating business disruption risk without the procedural protections standard in comparable jurisdictions.

keyConcerns.title: Penalty Enforces Digital Infrastructure Lock-in
keyConcerns.description: This general penalty clause (2,000-10,000 penalty units) enforces the bill's unprecedented **mandatory .gh domain registration requirement** ([19](#19-mandatory-registration)), creating substantial financial consequences for digital businesses that don't comply. The penalty reinforces a regulatory framework that forces all legally registered entities to use government-controlled digital infrastructure for their official online presence, limiting flexibility in digital strategy and creating barriers to innovation. Combined with additional enforcement mechanisms like **business license suspension and public contract exclusion** ([21](#21-penalties-for-non-compliance)), this creates a chilling effect on digital experimentation and disproportionately impacts startups and digital-native businesses with limited resources.

keyConcerns.title: Disproportionate Penalties for Administrative Non-Compliance
keyConcerns.description: This provision establishes a **general penalty of 2,000-10,000 penalty units** for any violation where no specific penalty is provided. While general penalty clauses are standard legislative technique, this one creates disproportionate enforcement burdens when applied to the mandatory .gh domain registration requirement. The penalty operates **cumulatively** with other enforcement mechanisms—annual fines ([21](#21-penalties-for-non-compliance)), business license suspension/revocation, public contract exclusion, and domain seizure ([24](#24-court-orders-and-judicial-support))—creating an overwhelming compliance burden for businesses, particularly SMEs. The **summary conviction process** may not provide adequate procedural safeguards given the severity of business consequences for what is essentially administrative non-compliance with a registration mandate.

provisions.title: Application and objects
provisions.plainLanguage: This law applies to the Ghana Domain Name Registry, its licensed registrars, and anyone who registers a .gh domain name. The law aims to set up the Ghana Domain Name Registry and regulate the .gh domain name system. It also establishes a fund for the registry and requires entities in Ghana to use the .gh domain name.
provisions.impactReasoning:
This provision is a foundational/procedural section that establishes the scope and objects of the Act. It does not itself impose substantive requirements, restrictions, or obligations—rather, it defines what the Act covers and its stated purposes.

**Scope of Application (Section 1):**
The provision identifies three categories of entities subject to the Act: the Registry itself, licensed registrars, and registrants. This is a standard definitional approach that clarifies jurisdictional reach. It does not create new obligations or restrictions at this stage; those are established in subsequent provisions (particularly the mandatory registration requirement in provision 19).

**Objects of the Act (Section 2):**
The stated objects include:
- Establishing the Registry (institutional creation)
- Regulating the .gh domain space (standard regulatory function)
- Establishing the Domain Name Registry Fund (financial mechanism)
- Mandating use of .gh domain names (substantive requirement—but stated here as an object, with implementation in provision 19)
- Providing for ancillary matters (catch-all)

**Assessment Against Democratic Principles:**

1. **Legal Certainty & Rule of Law:** The provision provides clear scope and stated purposes, which supports legal certainty. However, the breadth of "ancillary matters" is somewhat open-ended, though this is standard in enabling legislation.

2. **Separation of Powers & Democratic Accountability:** The provision itself does not concentrate power or bypass oversight mechanisms. It establishes what the Act will do, with subsequent provisions detailing governance structures (board appointments, parliamentary reporting, ministerial directives).

3. **Proportionality & Due Process:** As a definitional provision, it does not impose penalties, restrictions, or coercive measures. The substantive impacts (mandatory registration, penalties, licensing) are addressed in later provisions.

4. **Impact on Topic Areas:**

   - **Digital Innovation:** The provision's statement of objects includes establishing regulatory infrastructure and a development fund. The scope is neutral at this stage—it neither enables nor restricts innovation directly. However, the stated object to "mandate the use of the .gh domain name" signals a significant structural requirement that will be assessed when examining provision 19. This provision itself is neutral.

   - **Freedom of Speech:** No direct impact. The provision does not address content regulation, speech restrictions, or platform obligations.

   - **Privacy & Data Rights:** No direct impact. The provision does not establish data handling, retention, or access requirements.

   - **Business Environment:** The provision's scope includes "registrants of .gh domain names" and establishes a regulatory framework. The stated object to mandate .gh domain use will have significant business environment implications (assessed in provision 19), but this provision itself is procedural and neutral. It does not impose compliance burdens or barriers at this stage.

**Contextual Considerations:**
The following provision establishes the Registry as a body corporate and non-profit entity. This provision sets the stage for that institutional creation but does not itself create obligations or restrictions. The mandatory registration requirement (provision 19) is stated as an object here but implemented separately, so its impacts are assessed there, not here.

**Conclusion:**
This is a standard opening/definitional provision found in most enabling legislation. It clarifies scope and states purposes without imposing substantive requirements, restrictions, or obligations. It supports legal certainty by clearly defining what the Act covers. It does not depart from or enhance democratic norms—it simply establishes the framework within which subsequent substantive provisions operate.

provisions.title: Establishment of the Domain Name Registry
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision formally establishes the Ghana Domain Name Registry. The Registry is created as a self-governing body with the ability to manage its own affairs and operate under its own name. It will function as a non-profit entity.
provisions.rawText:
- (1) There is established by this Act the Ghana Domain Name Registry.

    - The Registry is a body corporate with perpetual succession and a common seal and may sue and be sued in its corporate name.

    - The Registry is a non-profit making entity.
provisions.impactReasoning:
This provision establishes the Ghana Domain Name Registry as a body corporate with perpetual succession, common seal, and legal capacity to sue and be sued. It is a non-profit entity. This is a foundational, procedural provision that creates the institutional framework for the Registry's operations.

**Assessment of Direct Impact:**

1. **Institutional Structure**: The provision creates a legal entity with standard corporate characteristics (perpetual succession, common seal, legal capacity). This is routine institutional establishment language found in many regulatory frameworks.

2. **Non-profit Status**: The explicit designation as non-profit is significant in context. Given the bill's mandatory domain registration requirements ([19](#19-mandatory-registration)) with substantial penalties, and the Registry's revenue-generating functions (licensing registrars, service fees), the non-profit designation provides some constraint against profit extraction. However, this is a structural designation rather than a substantive operational safeguard.

3. **Relationship to Following Provision**: The following provision establishes the Registry's duties, including conducting investigations, research, audits, and issuing information. The non-profit status combined with these investigative and audit powers creates a framework where the Registry operates as both regulator and investigator without explicit independent oversight mechanisms at this stage.

4. **Rule of Law Considerations**: 
   - The provision itself is clear and certain in its legal effect
   - Non-profit status provides some protection against conflicts of interest, though not absolute
   - The provision lacks explicit safeguards regarding independence, accountability, or checks on the Registry's powers (these may appear elsewhere in the bill)
   - The institutional framework is standard for regulatory bodies in democratic jurisdictions

5. **Context of Mandatory Requirements**: The bill context reveals this Registry will enforce mandatory .gh domain registration with significant penalties. The non-profit designation is a modest safeguard but does not address the broader concerns about concentrated regulatory power, mandatory infrastructure use, or enforcement discretion that emerge from the full bill.

6. **Democratic Standards**: Establishing a non-profit regulatory body is consistent with international practice (ICANN, various national registries). However, the provision alone does not establish the governance safeguards, independence protections, or accountability mechanisms that characterize best-practice regulatory bodies.

**Impact Analysis by Topic:**

- **Digital Innovation**: The non-profit status and institutional establishment are neutral to slightly positive. Non-profit designation prevents profit-driven distortions in domain policy. However, the provision itself is merely structural and doesn't directly enable or inhibit innovation.

- **Freedom of Speech**: Neutral. The provision establishes institutional structure without direct speech implications. The following provision's investigative powers raise potential concerns, but this provision itself is neutral.

- **Privacy & Data Rights**: Neutral. The provision creates institutional structure without direct privacy implications.

- **Business Environment**: Neutral to slightly negative. The non-profit designation is neutral. However, in context of mandatory registration and the Registry's regulatory powers, the institutional framework creates a concentrated regulatory authority. The provision itself is neutral, but combined with mandatory requirements and enforcement powers, it establishes the entity that will enforce those requirements.

**Confidence Considerations**: This is a straightforward institutional establishment provision. The language is clear and standard. However, assessing its impact requires understanding how it functions within the broader bill's mandatory requirements and enforcement mechanisms. The provision itself is procedurally sound but operates within a potentially problematic regulatory framework.

provisions.title: Duties of the Registry
provisions.plainLanguage: The Registry is responsible for promoting the benefits of domain name registration to the public. It must research and monitor the domain name system, assess how well the .gh domain space meets the needs of Ghanaians, and provide information on domain name registration. The Registry also audits licensed registrars and evaluates the effectiveness of the law governing domain names, and can collaborate with other organizations and experts.
provisions.impactReasoning:
This provision establishes the Registry's duties, which are primarily procedural and administrative in nature. The duties include: enhancing public awareness, conducting investigations, researching domain name system developments, surveying citizen needs, issuing information, auditing registrars, evaluating the Act's effectiveness, and liaising with other entities.

**Digital Innovation Impact Analysis:**
The provision establishes foundational Registry functions that support the digital ecosystem. The duties to conduct research, keep abreast of developments, survey citizen needs, and evaluate effectiveness are positive governance practices that enable informed policy-making. The ability to conduct investigations and audit registrars provides oversight mechanisms. However, this provision alone is neutral—it establishes administrative duties without creating barriers or enablers. When read with the following provision (which establishes monopoly control and mandatory government email hosting), these duties become part of a broader framework that could restrict innovation, but the current provision itself is procedurally sound.

**Freedom of Speech Impact Analysis:**
The provision has minimal direct impact on freedom of speech. The duty to "issue information on the registration of domain names" is informational and supportive. The provision does not restrict speech, impose content monitoring, or create censorship mechanisms. It is neutral on this dimension.

**Privacy & Data Rights Impact Analysis:**
The provision includes authority to "conduct investigations related to its functions" and "conduct biennial audits on all licensed registrars." These investigative and audit powers could potentially involve data access, but the provision does not specify the scope, nature, or safeguards for such investigations. The provision lacks explicit privacy protections or data handling requirements. However, the provision itself does not mandate data collection or surveillance—it merely authorizes investigations within the Registry's functions. This is moderately concerning from a data protection perspective due to lack of specificity, but not severe. The provision should ideally include privacy safeguards and limitations on investigative scope.

**Business Environment Impact Analysis:**
The provision establishes Registry duties that are generally supportive of the business environment. The duty to enhance public awareness, conduct research, survey citizen needs, and evaluate effectiveness supports informed decision-making. The audit function provides necessary oversight of registrars. However, the provision is primarily administrative and does not directly create barriers or facilitate market entry. It is neutral on balance—neither significantly improving nor hindering the business environment. The provision becomes problematic when combined with the following provision's monopoly structure and mandatory government infrastructure requirements, but this provision alone is procedurally appropriate.

**Confidence Assessment:**
This is a straightforward administrative provision with clear duties. The impacts are relatively predictable and well-defined. Confidence is high because the provision's scope and effects are clear, though some uncertainty exists regarding how investigative powers will be exercised in practice.

provisions.title: Functions of the Registry
provisions.plainLanguage: The Registry manages Ghana's (.gh) domain name space, ensuring its proper function and security. It licenses registrars, provides secure email to government bodies, and publishes guidelines for domain name registration and web standards. The Registry also audits government web applications and ensures compliance with the Act for all .gh domain-related activities.
provisions.impactReasoning:
This provision establishes the Registry's core functions and operational mandate. Key elements to assess:

**Digital Innovation Impact:**
The provision creates a monopoly structure (Registry is "the only domain name Registry") with exclusive control over .gh domain space. While this ensures unified management and compliance with international best practices (1(c)), it creates a single point of control that could inhibit innovation in domain services. However, the provision also mandates DNSSEC implementation (1(e)), which is a security best practice, and requires compliance with international standards. The licensing and regulation of registrars (1(f)) allows market participation but under Registry control. The provision itself is neutral-to-slightly-negative on innovation because it establishes monopoly control, though this is partially offset by the requirement to comply with international best practices and the structured registrar licensing framework.

**Freedom of Speech Impact:**
The provision has limited direct speech impact. It establishes technical infrastructure management and administrative functions. However, the monopoly control over domain space combined with the Registry's power to audit government web applications (1(i)) and the following provision's board composition (which includes law enforcement) creates potential for speech restrictions through domain denial or content monitoring. The provision itself doesn't directly restrict speech, but it establishes the infrastructure through which speech could be restricted. The requirement to "publish guidelines" (1(h)) on registration requirements and repository access suggests transparency, which is positive. Overall, the provision is neutral on direct speech impact, though it establishes mechanisms that could be used to restrict speech.

**Privacy & Data Rights Impact:**
The provision mandates secure email hosting with end-to-end encryption for government entities (1(g)), which is a positive privacy protection. The requirement to maintain and provide public access to the repository (1(h)(iv)) with "due regard to policy directives" creates some ambiguity about data protection standards. The auditing function (1(i)) could involve access to sensitive data. The provision is moderately positive because it explicitly mandates encryption for government communications, though the vague language around "policy directives" and repository access creates some uncertainty.

**Business Environment Impact:**
The monopoly structure (Registry as "the only domain name Registry") creates a significant barrier to market entry for competing registry operators. This is a high-negative impact on business environment because it prevents competition in registry services. However, the provision allows for multiple registrars through licensing (1(f)), which partially mitigates this. The requirement to comply with international best practices (1(c)) and the structured licensing framework provide some assurance of fair treatment. The provision is high-negative because it establishes an exclusive monopoly without competitive alternatives, which is a substantial barrier to business innovation in registry services.

**Interaction with Following Provision:**
The following provision establishes the Board composition with presidential appointment, ministerial nominees, law enforcement representation, and academic/technical community input. This creates a governance structure with significant government influence (Minister nominates 2 members, Interior nominates 1 from law enforcement). Combined with the current provision's monopoly grant, this creates a government-controlled monopoly over domain infrastructure, which amplifies the business environment and potential speech concerns.

**Rule of Law Considerations:**
- The monopoly grant is clear and legally certain (positive for rule of law)
- The requirement to comply with international best practices provides external accountability (positive)
- The vague language around "policy directives" creates some legal uncertainty (negative)
- The exclusive control without competitive safeguards raises separation of powers concerns when combined with government board control (negative)

**Overall Assessment:**
The provision is primarily neutral to slightly negative. It establishes clear functions and mandates international best practices compliance, which are positive. However, the monopoly structure without competitive alternatives creates barriers to business innovation and digital market entry. The encryption mandate for government communications is a positive privacy protection. The provision's impact is significantly amplified by the following provision's board composition, which concentrates government control over this monopoly.

provisions.title: Governing Body of the Registry
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision establishes the governing board for the Registry, which includes representatives from various sectors such as government, law enforcement, universities, the internet community, and legal experts. The President appoints the board members, with a requirement to include at least three women. The board is responsible for overseeing the Registry's operations and ensuring it functions effectively.
provisions.impactReasoning:
This provision establishes the governance structure for the Ghana Domain Name Registry Board. The assessment must evaluate the provision's direct impact on the four topic areas, considering it within the context of the broader bill's mandatory .gh domain registration requirements and enforcement mechanisms.

**Governance Structure Analysis:**

The Board composition includes:
- Executive Director (Registry staff)
- Two ministerial nominees (one from ministry agencies)
- One law enforcement representative (Interior Ministry)
- One internet technical community representative
- One public university representative
- One private university representative
- One legal expert (7+ years IP/cyber law)
- One licensed local registrar representative
- Mandatory minimum of 3 women members

**Separation of Powers & Rule of Law Concerns:**

The provision creates a mixed governance model with significant executive influence. The President appoints all members (including those nominated by others), and two of eight voting members are directly ministerial nominees. This creates potential conflicts:

1. **Executive Dominance**: The President's appointment power over all members, combined with ministerial nomination rights, concentrates significant control in the executive branch. The law enforcement representative adds another executive-aligned voice.

2. **Conflict of Interest**: The Registry is both the monopoly operator of .gh domains AND the enforcer of mandatory registration requirements with substantial penalties. Board members include the Executive Director (who benefits from enforcement) and a licensed registrar (who may benefit from competitors' penalties). This creates misaligned incentives.

3. **Limited Independent Oversight**: While the legal expert and academic representatives provide some independence, they are outnumbered by executive-aligned members. The internet technical community representative is the only truly independent technical voice.

**Positive Elements:**

- Gender representation requirement (minimum 3 women) enhances democratic representation
- Inclusion of technical community, academics, and legal expertise provides some professional balance
- Four-year terms with two-term limits (in following provision) prevent indefinite executive control
- Diverse nomination sources create some checks on pure executive appointment
- Constitutional appointment procedures (article 70) provide procedural legitimacy

**Impact Assessment by Topic:**

**Digital Innovation Impact:**
The governance structure's impact on innovation depends on Board independence and technical competence. The inclusion of internet technical community and academic representatives is positive. However, the executive dominance and conflict of interest (Registry profits from enforcement of mandatory registration) could bias decisions toward regulatory expansion rather than market-friendly innovation. The mandatory .gh requirement itself (from preceding context) creates barriers, but this provision's governance structure doesn't directly address that—it establishes who decides. The mixed composition with technical representation provides some protection against purely anti-innovation decisions, but executive influence limits this.

**Freedom of Speech Impact:**
The Board will make decisions affecting domain registration policies, dispute resolution, and potentially content-related matters (given the Registry's role in DNS security). The executive-heavy composition could enable speech-restrictive policies. However, the legal expert requirement and academic representation provide some safeguards. The provision itself doesn't directly restrict speech, but establishes the body that will make speech-affecting decisions. The conflict of interest (Registry benefits from enforcement) could incentivize restrictive policies.

**Privacy & Data Rights Impact:**
The Registry operates secure email hosting and DNS security operations. Board governance affects privacy policy decisions. The legal expert with IP/cyber law expertise is relevant here. However, the executive dominance and law enforcement representative could bias toward surveillance-friendly policies. The provision doesn't directly establish privacy protections or weaknesses—it establishes governance for the body that will make such decisions.

**Business Environment Impact:**
This is the most significant impact area. The Board will decide on registrar licensing, domain registration requirements, and enforcement of the mandatory .gh requirement. The inclusion of a licensed registrar representative is positive (industry voice), but creates potential conflicts of interest. The executive dominance means the Board is likely to support the mandatory registration regime and its enforcement, which creates substantial business barriers (as established in the bill's mandatory registration provisions). The governance structure doesn't mitigate the mandatory requirement's negative business impact—it establishes the body that will enforce it.

**Separation of Powers Concerns:**

The provision creates a problematic concentration where:
- The Registry (enforcer of mandatory registration) is governed by a Board
- The Board includes the Executive Director (who benefits from enforcement)
- The Board includes a licensed registrar (who may benefit from competitors' penalties)
- The Board is majority-controlled by executive appointees
- The Registry has power to recommend penalties, obtain court orders, and publicly list violators

This violates the principle that enforcers should not profit from enforcement and that oversight should be independent. While not as severe as if the Registry directly profited from fines, the structural incentive misalignment is significant.

**Comparative Analysis:**

In OECD democracies, domain registries typically have:
- Independent boards with majority non-executive representation
- Separation between policy-making and enforcement
- Explicit conflict-of-interest provisions
- Technical community dominance in technical decisions
- Limited government representation

This provision deviates from those norms by concentrating executive control and creating enforcement conflicts.

**Overall Assessment:**

The provision establishes governance that is within the range of democratic practice but with significant structural weaknesses. The mandatory gender representation and diverse nomination sources are positive. However, the executive dominance, law enforcement representation, and conflict of interest (Registry benefits from enforcement of mandatory registration) create governance problems that exceed norms in most OECD democracies. The provision doesn't directly violate rule of law principles but creates conditions enabling problematic decisions.

The impact varies by topic:
- **Digital Innovation**: Medium-negative (executive dominance could bias against innovation; mandatory registration regime enforced by this Board creates barriers)
- **Freedom of Speech**: Medium-negative (executive-heavy Board could enable restrictive policies; law enforcement representation raises surveillance concerns)
- **Privacy & Data Rights**: Low-negative to neutral (legal expert provides some protection; executive dominance creates surveillance risk)
- **Business Environment**: High-negative (Board will enforce mandatory .gh requirement with substantial penalties; registrar representative creates conflict of interest; executive dominance ensures enforcement-friendly policies)

The business environment impact is most significant because the Board directly governs enforcement of the mandatory registration requirement that creates substantial compliance burdens and penalties.

provisions.title: Tenure of office of Board members
provisions.plainLanguage: Board members can serve up to four years and be reappointed for a maximum of two consecutive terms. Vacancies on the Board are filled by presidential appointment, based on advice from a nominating authority and consultation with the Council of State. A member who misses three meetings in a row without a good reason will be removed, and members can resign by writing to the President through the Minister.
provisions.rawText:
- (1) A member of the Board shall hold office for a period not exceeding four years and is eligible for reappointment, but a member shall not be appointed for more than two terms in succession.

    - Where a member of the Board, resigns, dies, is removed from office or is for a reasonable cause unable to act as a member, the Minister shall notify the President of  the  vacancy  and  the  President  shall,  acting  on  the  advice  of  the  nominating authority and in consultation with the Council  of State appoint another person to hold office for the unexpired portion of the member's term of office.

    - A member of the Board, who is absent from three consecutive meetings of the Board without reasonable cause ceases to be a member of the Board.

    - A member of the Board, may at any time resign from office in writing addressed to the President through the Minister.

  - (1) The Board shall meet at least once every three months for the despatch of business at the times and in the places determined by the chairperson.

    - The  chairperson shall at the request in writing of not less than one-third of the membership of the Board convene an extraordinary meeting of the Board at the place and time determined by the chairperson.

    - The quorum at a meeting of the Board shall be two thirds of members of the Board or a greater number determined by the Board in respect of specific matters.

    - The chairperson shall preside at meetings of the Board and in the absence of the chairperson a member of the Board elected by the members present from among their number shall preside.

    - Matters before the Board shall be decided by a majority of the members present and voting and in the event of an equality of votes, the person presiding shall have a casting vote.

    - The Board may co-opt a person to attend a Board meeting, but that person shall not vote on a matter for decision at the meeting.

    - The proceedings of the Board shall not be invalidated because of a vacancy among the members or a defect in the appointment or qualification of a member.

    - Subject to this section, the Board may determine the procedure for its meetings.
provisions.impactReasoning:
This provision establishes governance structures and procedures for the Registry Board, including member tenure, appointment processes, meeting requirements, and decision-making procedures. The assessment must consider how these governance arrangements affect the four impact areas.

**Governance Structure Analysis:**

The provision establishes:
1. Four-year terms with two-term succession limits (preventing indefinite tenure)
2. Presidential appointment with Council of State consultation (constitutional alignment)
3. Quarterly meetings with quorum requirements (2/3 majority)
4. Majority voting with casting vote provisions
5. Automatic removal for three consecutive unexcused absences
6. Conflict of interest disclosure requirements (in following provision)

**Rule of Law & Separation of Powers Considerations:**

The provision demonstrates several positive governance features:
- **Term limits**: Two consecutive terms prevent entrenchment and ensure regular renewal
- **Diverse nomination sources**: Board includes internet technical community, universities, law enforcement, legal experts, and registrars—creating checks against capture by any single interest
- **Procedural safeguards**: Quorum requirements (2/3), majority voting, and casting vote provisions prevent arbitrary decision-making
- **Transparency mechanisms**: Regular quarterly meetings and documented procedures
- **Conflict of interest framework**: Combined with the following provision's disclosure requirements, creates accountability

However, there are concerns:
- **Presidential appointment authority**: While subject to Council of State consultation, the President retains significant control over board composition
- **Law enforcement representation**: The inclusion of a law enforcement nominee on a body managing critical internet infrastructure could create conflicts of interest, particularly given the Registry's enforcement powers (domain seizure, business license suspension)
- **Executive Director dual role**: The Executive Director serves as both board member and operational head, potentially concentrating power

**Impact on Digital Innovation:**

The governance structure's impact on innovation is mixed:
- **Positive**: Diverse board composition including technical community and universities supports innovation-oriented decision-making
- **Positive**: Term limits and regular meetings prevent stagnation
- **Concern**: Law enforcement representation and presidential control could bias decisions toward restrictive rather than innovation-enabling policies
- **Concern**: The board's authority over mandatory .gh domain registration (per provision 19) means governance structure directly affects whether innovation-friendly or restrictive policies prevail

**Impact on Freedom of Speech:**

The governance structure has indirect but significant implications:
- **Concern**: Law enforcement representation on a board managing critical internet infrastructure creates potential for speech-restrictive policies
- **Concern**: Presidential appointment authority could enable political influence over domain management
- **Positive**: Diverse stakeholder representation (universities, technical community, legal experts) provides counterbalance
- **Positive**: Conflict of interest disclosure requirements (following provision) create some accountability

**Impact on Privacy & Data Rights:**

Limited direct impact, but:
- **Positive**: Legal expert requirement and diverse composition support privacy-conscious decision-making
- **Concern**: Law enforcement representation could bias toward surveillance-enabling policies
- **Neutral**: The provision itself doesn't establish data handling procedures

**Impact on Business Environment:**

The governance structure affects business environment through:
- **Positive**: Registrar representation on board ensures business voice in decision-making
- **Positive**: Term limits and regular meetings prevent arbitrary policy changes
- **Concern**: Presidential control and law enforcement representation could enable restrictive policies
- **Concern**: The board's authority over mandatory registration and enforcement (per provisions 19-24) means governance structure directly affects compliance burden on businesses

**Comparative Analysis:**

Against international standards:
- **OECD governance principles**: The provision aligns with multi-stakeholder governance models common in internet governance (similar to ICANN structures)
- **Commonwealth practice**: Presidential appointment with Council of State consultation follows established constitutional practice
- **Concern**: Law enforcement representation on a regulatory body managing critical infrastructure is less common in OECD democracies and creates potential conflicts

**Interaction with Adjacent Provisions:**

The preceding provision (Governing Body composition) establishes the board's diverse membership. This tenure provision operationalizes that diversity through term limits and procedures. The following provision (Disclosure of interest) strengthens accountability by requiring conflict disclosure and automatic removal for violations.

Together, these provisions create a governance framework that:
- Prevents indefinite tenure and entrenchment
- Ensures regular renewal and fresh perspectives
- Requires conflict disclosure
- Maintains diverse stakeholder representation

However, the framework's effectiveness depends on whether the board uses its authority to enable or restrict digital innovation and business activity. Given the bill's mandatory .gh domain requirement and enforcement powers, the governance structure's impact is significant.

**Overall Assessment:**

This is a procedural governance provision that establishes institutional structures and decision-making processes. It demonstrates several best practices (term limits, diverse representation, quorum requirements, conflict disclosure) but includes concerning elements (law enforcement representation, presidential appointment authority). The provision itself is neutral-to-positive on governance principles, but its practical impact depends on how the board exercises its substantial authority over mandatory domain registration and enforcement.

The provision should be rated as having:
- **Medium-positive impact on Digital Innovation**: Diverse board composition supports innovation, but law enforcement representation and presidential control create uncertainty
- **Low-positive impact on Freedom of Speech**: Diverse representation provides some safeguard, but law enforcement presence creates concern
- **Low-positive impact on Privacy & Data Rights**: Similar to freedom of speech—diverse representation helps, but law enforcement presence is concerning
- **Medium-positive impact on Business Environment**: Registrar representation and term limits support business interests, but presidential control and enforcement authority create uncertainty

The confidence is moderate (0.65-0.70) because the provision's practical impact depends heavily on how the board exercises its discretionary authority, which is not fully determined by this provision alone.

provisions.title: Disclosure of interest
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision requires board members to disclose any personal interests related to matters the board is considering. A board member with a conflict of interest cannot participate in discussions about that matter. Failure to disclose a conflict of interest will result in the board member's removal.
provisions.rawText:
- (1) A member of the Board who has an interest in a matter for consideration by the Board  shall  disclose  in  writing  the  nature  of  that  interest  and  is  disqualified  from participating in the deliberations of the Board in respect of that matter.

    - A member who contravenes subsection (1) ceases to be a member.
provisions.impactReasoning:

- Democratic accountability (preventing self-dealing)
- Institutional integrity

- Commonwealth constitutions and governance frameworks routinely include such provisions
- EU governance standards mandate similar disclosures
- This is standard practice in regulatory bodies across OECD democracies

- The consequence is proportionate (disqualification from deliberations, not arbitrary punishment)
- The automatic removal for contravention provides a meaningful enforcement mechanism
- The provision protects the integrity of Board decision-making on matters that could affect the Registry's operations, including domain licensing, fee-setting, and enforcement actions

- The following provision on committee appointments shows the Board will delegate functions, making conflict-of-interest protections even more important
- Given the Registry's regulatory powers (licensing registrars, enforcing mandatory .gh registration, imposing penalties), conflict-of-interest safeguards are particularly important to prevent self-dealing

**Potential concerns:**

However, it has a modest positive impact on the business environment because:

- It reduces the risk of arbitrary or self-interested regulatory decisions
- It enhances confidence in the regulatory framework
- It prevents conflicts that could disadvantage compliant businesses

The provision represents standard good governance practice—not exceptional, but important for institutional integrity.

provisions.title: Establishment of committees
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision allows the Board to form committees to carry out specific tasks. These committees can be composed of Board members, outside experts, or a mix of both. Board members on committees serve as long as they are on the Board, while non-members can serve up to two four-year terms.

- (1) The Board may appoint committees consisting of members of the Board or nonmembers or both to perform a function.

    - The membership of a committee appointed under this section and the tenure of office of its members shall be coterminous with the duration of their membership of the Board.

    - Non-members shall hold office for a period not exceeding four years and may be eligible for re-appointment but shall not be appointed for more than two successive terms.

provisions.rawText: - Members  of  the  Board  and  members  of  a  committee  of  the  Board  shall  be  paid allowances approved by the Minister in consultation with the Minister responsible for Finance.

provisions.title: Policy Directives
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision allows the Minister to issue policy guidelines for managing and regulating the .gh domain name space. These directives will provide instructions on how the .gh domain, which represents Ghana on the internet, should be maintained and operated. This ensures there are clear rules and procedures for the .gh domain.
provisions.rawText: - The Minister may, from time to time, publish policy directives relating to the regulation and maintenance of the .gh domain name space.
provisions.impactReasoning:

1. **Scope and Constraints**: The directives are limited to "regulation and maintenance of the .gh domain name space"—a defined subject matter that provides some boundary on ministerial discretion.

   - Define compliance standards that entities must meet
   - Establish technical requirements for .gh domain use
   - Clarify exemption criteria
   - Set operational procedures for registrars

   - No requirement for parliamentary approval or consultation before directives are published
   - No requirement for public notice-and-comment period
   - No explicit requirement that directives be tabled in Parliament
   - No sunset provisions or periodic review requirements
   - The provision states directives may be published "from time to time" with no frequency or timing constraints

4. **Rule of Law Concerns**:
   - **Legal Certainty**: Entities subject to mandatory .gh registration must comply with directives that can be changed unilaterally by the Minister without parliamentary oversight. This creates uncertainty about compliance obligations.
   - **Separation of Powers**: The Minister has executive power to establish binding rules affecting all registered entities without legislative check, beyond the bill's framework.
   - **Proportionality**: Given the severe penalties for non-compliance (license suspension, business exclusion, fines), the rules governing compliance should have stronger democratic legitimacy than ministerial directives alone.

provisions.title: Mandatory registration
provisions.plainLanguage: This provision requires all legally registered entities in the Republic to use a ".gh" domain name for their official online presence and digital communications. This includes registering and maintaining a ".gh" domain for any public-facing website or platform. Entities not currently using a ".gh" domain must switch within six months.

- (1) All entities legally registered or operating in the Republic shall be required to:

          - (a) register and maintain an active .gh domain name for any official website or digital platform intended for public access; and

          - (b) use  the  .gh  domain  name  for  all  official  digital  correspondence  and transactions conducted within or from the Republic.
